musicalLanguage.description: One of the most beloved jazz standards ever written. Originally titled 'In Other Words,' it became Frank Sinatra's signature after his 1964 recording. The melody descends in a graceful sequence through the circle of fifths, making it a perfect first jazz standard for piano students.
musicalLanguage.structure: ABAB — 32 bars. This excerpt: first 8 bars (A section)
keyMoments: Bar 1-2: Am7 — the melody begins on C5 and descends stepwise. Instantly recognizable.
Bar 3-4: Dm7 to G7 — the ii-V that defines the harmonic motion
Bar 7-8: Em7 to A7 — the iii-VI introduces a secondary dominant pull
teachingGoals: Descending stepwise melody — easy to memorize and sing
Basic jazz chord progression: vi - ii - V - I
Simple left-hand shell voicings with root and seventh
styleTips: Swing the eighth notes — long-short, not even
The melody should be legato and lyrical — imagine singing the words
Left hand keeps it simple — whole notes or half notes are fine for beginners

measures.teachingNote: Am7 — descending scale from C. This is the opening everyone knows.
The phrase lands on F and rests. Let the note ring.
Dm7 — same descending pattern, starting a step lower. Sequence!
G7 — phrase lands on E. The V chord wants to resolve to C.
CMaj7 — the I chord arrives! The melody continues its descent.
CMaj7 continues. Simple and elegant. Less is more.
Em7 — the iii chord. Pattern descends yet again. Notice the sequence.
A7 — secondary dominant. The phrase resolves to C4. Ready for the next section.
